prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to achieve the best possible sensitivity we will use the dual polarisation mode. For the spectral window covering the CO line we selected the frequency division mode (FDM) with spectral resolution of 2.756 km/s. The expected linewidths are of the order of 100 km/s, so we will bin the data to a spectral resolution of about 20km/s. For the other spectral windows tracing the continuum we selected the time division mode (TDM) to limit the data rate.

Our targets have optical sizes of ~3 arcsec (1 arcsec is 2 kpc at z~0.1). Their typical effective radii are 1-1.5 kpc, and thus our choice of angular resolution will allow us to resolve spatially all the objects in our galaxy sample and test whether the gas is located inside or outside the optical effective radius.

We assumed line FWHM of 100 km/s and that the galaxies in our sample are spread over 9 arcsec^2, apart from the fact that the gas will probably located in clumps and non-uniformities, for which reason we conservatively assume a filling factor of gas clumps of 50% for all our targets. Hence we request the quoted rms value per galaxy for 20 km/s channels to obtain >3 sigma detections per channel (higher at the peak). In order to attempt to measure the galaxy continuum, we will use the line-free region in all four spectral windows. Finally, the integration times were calculated with the OT assuming an average weather condition of the precipitable vapour of 5.186 mm (7th octile) for Band 3 and 0.913 mm (3rd octile) for band 7.

For the spectral window covering the CO line we selected the frequency division mode (FDM) with spectral resolution of 0.973 km/s. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Massive (M_stellar>8x10^10 M_Sun) galaxies undergo an accelerated evolution in comparison with lower mass galaxies. This has been shown at z>1.5, where many of them are already dead & dead, and displaying much smaller sizes (~5 times smaller on average) than their likely descendants, the huge Early-Type Galaxies (ETGs) in the local Universe. Simulations predict that these compact galaxies are the result of a violent starburst, linking their formation with the availability of molecular gas. There are a number of possible mechanisms advocated for the later quench of their stellar populations. Here we propose CO(3-2) and CO(1-0) observations of three low-z (z~0.1) counterparts of the high-z compact massive galaxies. By measuring for the first time their gas content and its spatial distribution, we will be able to point out which feedback agent shut down their star formation. We will conduct observations down to a gas mass limit of 1% of the stellar mass, comparable to local Universe observations of massive ETGs, and thus explaining the dramatic changes (from star forming disks to passive spheroids) of the most massive galaxies of the Universe during their history.
